text:
Secondary markets refer to the trading of previously issued bonds. While some
government bonds and corporate bonds are traded on exchanges, the great majority
of bond trading in the secondary market is made in the dealer, or over-the-counter,
market. Dealers post bid (purchase) prices and ask or offer (selling) prices for various
bond issues. The difference between the bid and ask prices is the dealer's spread. The
average spread is often between 10 and 12 basis points but varies across individual bonds
according to their liquidity and may be more than 50 basis points for an illiquid issue.
